datafield.subfield: sponsored by the American Folklife Center ; assisted by the National Council for the Traditional Arts.
11 sound tape reels : analog, 7 1/2 ips, double track, mono. and stereo. ; 10 in.
10 photographic prints : black and white ; various sizes

Manuscript materials, sound recordings, and photographs documenting the performance of African American Piedmont blues music; music of the Andes; bluegrass music; Scottish harp music and Gaelic songs; Omaha Indian music and dance; Spanish flamenco music and dance, and African American gospel music recorded live outdoors on Neptune Plaza in front of the Thomas Jefferson Building, Library of Congress, at concerts from April through October 1985, sponsored by the American Folklife Center and the National Council for the Traditional Arts.
Archive of Folk Culture (Library of Congress),
National Council for the Traditional Arts,

did.langmaterial: English, Scottish Gaelic, Omaha, and Spanish
did.abstract: Manuscript materials, sound recordings, and photographs documenting the performance of African American Piedmont blues music; music of the Andes; bluegrass music; Scottish harp music and Gaelic songs; Omaha Indian music and dance; Spanish flamenco music and dance, and African American gospel music recorded live outdoors on Neptune Plaza in front of the Thomas Jefferson Building, Library of Congress, at concerts from April through October 1985, sponsored by the American Folklife Center and the National Council for the Traditional Arts.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The 1985 Neptune Plaza Concert Series Collection consists of manuscript and print materials, audio recordings, and graphic materials that document the 1985 concert series sponsored by the American Folklife Center. The annual series, which began in 1977, features the presentation of folk traditions from many cultures. The concerts take place on the Neptune Plaza at the front of the Jefferson Building of the Library of Congress between May and September. Adverse weather conditions sometimes force the concerts indoors. The 1985 series was produced with the assistance of the National Council for the Traditional Arts.

The 1985 season consisted of the following:
Date Performers Place of Origin Subject
April 18 John Cephas and Phil Wiggins Maryland Blues music
May 23 Tahuantinsuyo District of Columbia Inca music of the Andes
June 20 Dry Branch Fire Squad Ohio Bluegrass music
July 18 Alison Kinnaird and Christine Primrose Scotland Scottish music
August 15 Omaha Indians Hethu'shka Society Nebraska Omaha music and dance
September 19 Ana Martínez District of Columbia Flamenco music and dance
October 15 The Gospel Music Workshop of America District of Columbia Gospel music

bioghist.head: Administrative History
bioghist.p: Documentation created and accessioned by the American Folklife Center in 1985.

note.p: The following terms have been used to index the description of this collection in the Library's online catalog. They are grouped by name of person or organization, by subject and listed alphabetically therein.

accessrestrict.head: Access
accessrestrict.p: Listening and viewing access to the collection is unrestricted. Duplication of the materials requires prior permission of the Center and may be governed by copyright and other restrictions.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: 1985 Neptune Plaza Concert Series Collection (AFC 1985/015), Archive of Folk Culture, American Folklife Center, Library of Congress, Washington, D.C.

row.entry: Members of the Hethu'shka or Warrior Society of the Omaha Tribe present traditional dances and songs, including a series of war dances and the Buffalo dance. The program is narrated by Dennis Hastings, historian and archivist. Print material, photographs, and slides: Folders 12-13, Envelopes 14-18; sound recording: RWB 1556.

Ana Martínez and company present Flamenco music, song, and dance. Pieces include Alegrias, Fandagos, and Sevillanas forms. The performers also explain and demonstrate various percussive accompaniments, and invite audience participation. Print material, photographs, and slides: Folders 14-17, Envelopes 21-25; sound recording: RWB 1566.
